Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Expectation2: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation2: A major supplier has threatened to halt all future shipments until a significant past-due invoice is settled.
Story:
My phone buzzed just as I was about to dial the supplier’s number. The message was from Mark, someone I’d met a few times at community events. “Hey! You know the area well—can you recommend a good restaurant for my anniversary tonight?” I stared at the screen, feeling the weight of two worlds pressing in. As an acquaintance, I wanted to be helpful, to respond quickly and thoughtfully. Mark was counting on me, and I didn’t want to let him down.

But the email from our major supplier still glared at me from my laptop. They’d made it clear: no payment, no more shipments. As the company’s accountant, it was my job to resolve this—fast. My boss expected me to handle it with urgency and professionalism, and the entire production schedule depended on my next move.

I felt my heart race, torn between the friendly obligation to Mark and the professional crisis demanding my immediate attention. Both roles pulled at me, each expecting my time and care, and I sat frozen, phone in one hand, mouse in the other, unsure which demand to answer first.
